sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Evaluate CBC prior to administration of chemotherapy, then monitor twice a week until recovery
  • Neutropenia (Severe), In nonmyeloid malignancies following myelosuppressive chemotherapy; Prophylaxis: 5 mcg/kg/day SUBQ no earlier than 24 hours after myelosuppressive chemotherapy; continue until neutrophil count passes nadir and has recovered to normal range; do not give within 24 hours prior to chemotherapy

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Safety and effectiveness have not been established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: Renal impairment, mild: No dosage adjustment needed; moderate to severe impairment has not been evaluated

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Neutropenia (Severe), In nonmyeloid malignancies following myelosuppressive chemotherapy; Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Hematologic:
  • -- capillary leak syndrome may occur with human granulocyte colony-stimulating factors; monitoring recommended
  • -- potentially fatal splenic rupture may occur with human granulocyte colony-stimulating factors; discontinue use if upper abdominal or shoulder pain occurs
  • -- sickle cell disease; severe and sometimes fatal sickle cell crises may occur with human granulocyte colony-stimulating factors; discontinue use if crisis occurs
  • Immunologic:
  • -- serious allergic reactions (eg, anaphylaxis) may occur with human granulocyte colony-stimulating factors, even with initial exposure; discontinue use if occurs
  • -- serious, allergic reactions to filgrastim or pegfilgrastim; do not administer
  • Respiratory:
  • -- acute respiratory distress syndrome may occur with human granulocyte colony-stimulating factors; discontinue use if occurs
  • Other:
  • -- tumor growth, including myeloid malignancies and myelodysplasia (unapproved uses); may occur

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Tbo-filgrastim is a granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) that increases neutrophil counts and activity by binding to G-CSF receptors and stimulating differentiation commitment and some end-cell functional activation.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Subcutaneous
  • If syringes are removed from refrigerator, administer within 5 days or return to the refrigerator for storage up to the expiration date
  • Avoid shaking
  • Syringes are single use; discard any unused portion
  • Assess each patient for ability to competently self-administer
  • Recommended injection sites are abdomen (excluding 2 inches around the navel), front of middle thighs, upper outer area of buttocks, and upper back portion of upper arms
  • Do not inject into areas that are red, tender, bruised, hard, or that have scars or stretch marks
  • Rotate injection sites

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• decreased duration of neutropenia-related sequelae (eg, fever, infections) and reduced neutrophil recovery time are indicative of efficacy
  • CBC; baseline and twice weekly until neutrophil recovery; including differential

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to avoid administration in areas that are tender, red, bruised, hardened or areas that have scarring or stretch marks.
  • Warn female patients of childbearing potential to avoid becoming pregnant while taking this drug as fetal harm may occur.
  • Drug may cause bone pain.
  • Instruct patient to report symptoms of splenic enlargement or rupture (eg, left upper abdominal or left shoulder pain).
  • Advise patient to report symptoms of dyspnea.
  • Tell patient to report symptoms of allergic reaction (ie, anaphylaxis, rash, urticaria).
  • Encourage patient to report symptoms of infection (ie, fever, redness, swelling).
  • If self administering, teach patient proper technique and placement of injections.
